content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Errors in Credit Use and Reporting Act" or the "SECURE Act." Legal recourse for consumers is provided. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Prevailing parties may also receive costs and attorney fees. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow courts to award injunctive relief for non-compliance with consumer protection requirements. Prevailing parties may also receive costs and attorney fees for successful actions. SEC. 3. INCREASED REQUIREMENTS FOR CONSUMER REPORTING AGENCIES AND FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in relevant information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include all documentation provided by consumers in relevant information, gathering and reporting information relating to consumer disputes. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require the Bureau to gather and report information on consumer disputes received by reporting agencies. Rules will be established for the type, format, and frequency of information to be provided. Compliance procedures for accuracy of reports are also updated. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to ensure maximum accuracy in consumer reports by following reasonable procedures. The Bureau will issue a proposed rule within a year to establish these procedures, including considerations for improving accuracy by matching specific information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to improve accuracy by matching specific consumer information, including names, dates of birth, social security numbers, and other relevant details. Furnishers of information must not include new information in reinvestigations. Disclosures to consumers will be amended accordingly. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with specific details for reinvestigations, including the address, telephone number, and permissible purpose of the person obtaining the consumer report. Additionally, consumers must be supplied with a credit score derived from a widely distributed credit scoring model. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with specific details for reinvestigations, including the address, telephone number, and permissible purpose of the person obtaining the consumer report. Credit scores derived from widely distributed models must be provided to consumers free of charge upon request. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with free disclosures of adverse information within 14 days of notification, as specified in subsections (a)(2) or (h)(6) of section 615. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now mandates that consumer reporting agencies must furnish consumers with free disclosures of adverse information within 14 days of notification, as outlined in subsections (a)(2) or (h)(6) of section 615. Additionally, before the Bureau finalizes the required rule under section 609(h), agencies must provide consumers with a copy of their current credit report and other necessary disclosures without any charges. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide consumers with free copies of their credit reports, including adverse information, within 14 days of notification. Amendments to section 615(h) specify that consumers must receive a copy of their consumer report free of charge and be informed of their right to dispute any information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates that consumer reporting agencies must provide consumers with free copies of their credit reports promptly. Amendments to the Act include notifying consumers of their right to dispute any information and ensuring that negative information submissions are properly disclosed. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide free credit reports to consumers promptly. Amendments to the Act include notifying consumers of their right to dispute information and ensuring proper disclosure of negative information. The Bureau is tasked with defining certain disclosure requirements to help consumers understand adverse actions taken against them and protect their privacy. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to provide free credit reports to consumers promptly, including procedures to ensure that such information is provided to the consumer at the appropriate address while protecting consumer privacy. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to furnish free credit reports to consumers promptly, ensuring privacy. Section 621 of the Act is amended to establish 3 public registries for different types of consumer reporting agencies, requiring all agencies to register within a specified timeframe. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on international credit systems, accuracy of existing consumer credit reporting systems, feasibility of a national government-administered system, consumer benefits, and costs. Findings will be published within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment, with certain exceptions.
